title: Pirates’ Felipe Vázquez Arrested for Solicitation of a Child
text:
Felipe Vázquez, the Pittsburgh Pirates’ All-Star closer, was arrested Tuesday on charges of child pornography and soliciting a teenage girl for sex, the Florida of Department of Law Enforcement said.

Pennsylvania State Police troopers took Vázquez into custody at his apartment in Pittsburgh and brought him to the Allegheny County Jail on a felony warrant out of Lee County, Fla. Investigators seized several electronic devices that will be examined as part of the investigation. Vázquez, 28, faces extradition to Florida. Later Tuesday, four additional charges were filed against Vázquez in Westmoreland County, Pa., including statutory sexual assault stemming from an incident in August 2018. He has been denied bail.

FDLE agents began investigating Vázquez in August after obtaining information that Vázquez had a sexual relationship with a 13-year-old. Authorities said the alleged victim, who is now 15, continued her relationship with Váquez over text message and in July received explicit images and a video that showed him performing a sex act.

Though the photographs and video didn’t show Vázquez’s face, the photos showed “unique and distinguishable” tattoos consistent with Vázquez’s, according to the arrest affidavit. The affidavit said that the alleged victim referred to the sender of the explicit messages as “Felipe” throughout the text message conversation. Additionally, Vázquez allegedly sent the girl text messages suggesting that they would meet for sex after the baseball season had ended. The alleged victim’s mother discovered the text messages several days later.

According to a Lee County Sheriff’s Office incident report from Aug. 5, the alleged victim received a text message from Vázquez at approximately 10:30 p.m. on July 29 that said, “I can’t wait to see you during the off season.” The alleged victim said she originally met Vázquez at a stadium in Pennsylvania, took a photograph with him outside the bullpen and then found him on social media, which began their years-long online relationship.

She told officers of one incident where Vázquez met with her at a previous residence. At one point during the visit, Vázquez allegedly pulled her pants down while they were inside his car, placed her on his lap and “attempted to penetrate her vagina with his penis, but was unsuccessful,” according to the incident report.

Vázquez has been charged with one count of giving obscene material to a minor and one count of soliciting a child for unlawful sexual conduct. Representatives for Vázquez didn’t immediately respond to a request for comment.

Pirates president Frank Coonelly said that the team was made aware of the investigation into Vázquez on Tuesday and informed the commissioner’s office. Vázquez will be placed on administrative leave pursuant to Major League Baseball’s joint domestic violence, sexual assault and child abuse policy.

“We take this matter, and these charges in particular, extremely seriously,” Coonelly said.

Vázquez was fined by the Pirates earlier this month following an altercation in the team’s clubhouse that resulted in fellow pitcher Kyle Crick undergoing season-ending finger surgery. At the time, Pirates general manager Neal Huntington said that Crick and Vázquez’s behavior was “unacceptable, inconsistent with the standards of a major-league player and will not be tolerated by the organization.”

In 56 appearances for the Pirates in 2019, Vázquez has posted a 1.65 ERA, converted 28 saves and struck out 90 batters in 60 innings. He is in the second season of a four-year contract that guarantees him $22 million contract, with club options that could increase his compensation to $41 million.
